transport and deposition of soil sediment or rock fragments by action of water wind ice or gravity erosion control plan means a written description and detailed site plan of best management practices designed to meet the requirements of this article submitted by the applicant for review and approval by the city extraterritorial means the unincorporated area within three miles of the corporate limits of a first second or third class city or within 1 miles of a fourthclass city fee in lieu means a payment of money to the city of delafield in place of meeting all or part of the erosion control or stormwater performance standards required by this article filtering layer means soil that has at least a threefoot deep layer with at least 20 percent that passes #200 sieve fines  or at least a fivefootdeep layer with at least ten percent that passes #200 sieve fines  or another medium exists with an equivalent level of protection as determined by the reviewer of the permit final stabilization means that all land disturbing construction activities at the construction site have been completed and that a uniform perennial vegetative cover has been established with a density of at least 70 percent of the cover for the unpaved areas and areas not covered by permanent structures or that employ equivalent permanent stabilization measures financial guarantee means an irrevocable letter of credit cash or similar guarantees submitted to the city by the permit holder to assure that requirements of this article are performed in compliance with the erosion control and stormwater plans gross aggregate area means the total area in acres of all land located within the property boundary containing the land development activity groundwater enforcement standard means a numerical value expressing the concentration of a substance in groundwater which is adopted under wis stats  16007 and  nr 14010 or wis stats  16009 and  nr 14012 groundwater preventive action limit means a numerical value expressing the concentration of a substance in groundwater which is adopted under wis stats  16015 and  nr 14010 14012 or 14020 illicit discharge means any discharge to a municipal separate storm sewer that is not composed entirely of runoff except discharges authorized by a wpdes permit or any other discharge not requiring a wpdes permit such as water line flushing landscape irrigation individual residential car washing firefighting and similar discharges impervious surface means an area that releases as runoff all or a large portion of the precipitation that falls on it except for frozen soil rooftops sidewalks driveways gravel or paved parking lots and streets are examples of surfaces that are typically impervious infill means an undeveloped area of land located within an existing urban sewer service area surrounded by development or development and natural or manmade features where development cannot occur infill does not include any undeveloped area that is part of a larger new development also requiring a permit infiltration means the process by which rainfall or surface runoff percolates or penetrates into the underlying soil irrevocable letter of credit means an agreement with a bank or other institution to pay money or extend credit to honor the terms of the permit with the city of delafield land development activity means the construction of buildings roads parking lots paved and unpaved storage areas patios seawalls and similar facilities but does not include agricultural land use or general maintenance of parking lots and drives land disturbing construction activity means any manmade alteration of the land surface resulting in a change in the topography or existing vegetative or nonvegetative soil cover that may result in runoff and lead to an increase in soil erosion and movement of sediment into waters of the state land disturbing construction activity includes clearing and grubbing demolition excavating dewatering dredging related to stormwater bmp maintenance filling and grading activities repaving is not considered a land disturbing construction activity unless the subgrade material below the pavement is removed replaced or significantly regraded land user means any person operating leasing renting or having made other arrangements with the landowner by which the landowner authorizes use of his or her land landowner or owner  means any person or entity holding fee title an easement or other interest in property which allows the person to undertake cropping livestock management land disturbing construction activity or maintenance of stormwater bmps on the property maintenance agreement means a legal document that is filed with the city clerk and recorded with waukesha county and which provides for longterm maintenance of erosion control or stormwater management practices maximum extent practicable or mep means an acceptable level of performance that is achievable but is not equivalent to a performance standard specified in this article mep may provide flexibility when assessing plan acceptability and may vary based on the performance standard and site conditions nonstorm discharge means a discharge to the storm sewer or drainage system created by some process other than the runoff of rain nonstructural measure means a practice technique or measure to reduce the volume peak flow rate or pollutants in stormwater that does not require the design or installation of fixed stormwater management facilities offsite means located outside the property boundary described in the permit application for land development activity other than residential development means development of the following land uses commercial  industrial  government and institutional  recreation  transportation  communication  and utilities peak flow discharge rate means the maximum rate at which a unit volume of stormwater is discharged performance security means an irrevocable letter of credit cash or similar guarantees submitted to the city of delafield by the permit holder to assure that requirements of this article are carried out in compliance with the erosion control and stormwater management plans permit administration fee means a sum of money paid to the city of delafield for the purpose of recouping the expenses incurred by the authority in administering the permit permit holder means any person or entity issued an erosion control andor storm water permit under this article or their successors in interest with respect to the property in which the permit applies see also definition of applicant pervious surface means an area that releases as runoff a small portion of the precipitation that falls on it lawns gardens parks forests or similar vegetated areas are examples of surfaces that typically are pervious postconstruction stormwater discharge means any stormwater discharged from a site following the completion of land disturbing construction activity and final site stabilization postdevelopment condition means the extent and distribution of land cover types anticipated to occur under conditions of full development that will influence rainfall runoff and infiltration predevelopment condition means the extent and distribution of land cover types present before the initiation of land development activity assuming that all land uses prior to development activity are managed in an environmentally sound manner pretreatment means the treatment of stormwater prior to its discharge to the primary stormwater treatment practice in order to reduce pollutant loads to a level compatible with the capability of the primary practice professional services reimbursement means that services provided by the city attorney city engineer city planner or any other of the citys professional staff results in a charge to the city for that professionals time and service and such service is not a service supplied to the city as a whole the city shall charge that service for the fees incurred by the city to the landowner or responsible party qualified professional means a professional landscape architect professional hydrologist or professional engineer licensed in wisconsin or a person certified in erosion control planning implementation or inspection residential development means that which is created to house people including the residential dwellings as well as all attendant portions of the development including lawns driveways sidewalks garages and access streets this type of development includes singlefamily multifamily apartment and trailer parks runoff means storm water or precipitation including rain snow ice melt or similar water that moves on the land surface via sheet or channelized flow site means the entire area included in the legal description of the land on which the land disturbing or land development activity is proposed site restriction means any physical characteristic which limits the use of a stormwater best management practice stabilize means that vegetation is well established or other surfacing material is in place and the risk of further soil erosion is minimal stop work order means an order issued by the city which requires that all construction activity on the site be stopped except for any prescribed work needed to be completed to bring a site back into compliance stormwater management measure means a practice technique or measure to reduce the volume peak flow rate or pollutants in stormwater including but not limited to structural stormwater measures stormwater management plan means a document that identifies what actions will be taken to reduce stormwater quantity and pollutant loads from land development activity to levels meeting the purpose and intent of this article structural measure means a source area practice conveyance measure or endofpipe treatment designed to control erosion and stormwater runoff pollutant loads discharge volumes and peak flow discharge rates surface waters means all lakes bays rivers streams springs ponds wells impounding reservoirs marshes water courses drainage systems or groundwater natural or artificial public or private within the city of delafield except those waters which are entirely confined and retained completely upon the property of a person top of channel means an edge or point on the landscape commencing landward from the ordinary high water mark of a surface water of the state where the slope of the land begins to be less than 12 percent continually for at least 50 feet if the slope of the land is 12 percent or less continually for the initial 50 feet landward from the ordinary high water mark the top of the channel is the ordinary high water mark waters of the state means those portions of lake michigan and lake superior within the boundaries of wisconsin and all lakes bays rivers streams springs ponds wells impounding reservoirs marshes watercourses drainage systems and other surface water or groundwater natural or artificial public or private within the state or its jurisdiction wet detention basin is a detention basin with a permanent pool of water often designed to trap particulate pollutants wetlands mean an area inundated or saturated by surface or groundwater at a frequency or duration sufficient to support a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions these wetlands include natural mitigation and restored wetlands working day means a calendar day except saturdays sundays and state and cityrecognized legal holidays 04 jurisdiction a this article applies to land disturbing and land development activities on the lands within the boundaries and jurisdiction of the city of delafield and within its extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction under wis stats ch 236 b exemptions this article does not apply to land development activities conducted or contracted by any state agency as defined under wis stats  227011 but also including the office of district attorney 05 general administration the common council has designated the director of public works to administer and enforce the provisions of this article the director of public works shall oversee the administration of this article and working in consonance with the public works committee city administrator city engineer and building inspector will review erosion control and stormwater management plans issue permits as appropriate and monitor the effectiveness of land development measures 06 secs 1626816297  reserved division 2  construction site erosion control control of erosion and pollutants a applicability this section applies to the following sites of land development or land disturbing activities 1 those requiring a subdivision plat approval or the construction of houses or commercial industrial or institutional buildings on lots of approved subdivision or condominium plats 2 those requiring a certified survey map approval or the construction of houses or commercial industrial or institutional buildings on lots of approved certified survey maps 3 those involving grading removal of protective ground cover or vegetation excavation land filling or other land disturbing activity affecting a surface area of 3000 square feet or more 4 those involving excavation or filling or a combination of excavation and filling affecting 400 cubic yards or more of material 5 those involving the laying repairing replacing or enlarging of an underground utility pipe or other facility or the disturbance of road ditch grass swale or other open channel for a distance of 300 feet or more 6 those involving grading removal of protective ground cover or vegetation excavation land filling or land disturbing activity within 200 feet of a lake stream or wetland when the work affects more than ten cubic yards of material 7 those involving deposit of sediment from lake or river dredging 8 those involving the maintenance of an existing storm water best management practice 9 those involving a land disturbing activity regardless of size that the city of delafield determines is likely to cause an adverse impact to an environmentally sensitive area or other property or may violate any other erosion control standard set forth in this article b exemptions this article does not apply to the following 1 construction projects that are exempted by state or federal statutes or regulations from the requirement to have a national pollutant discharge elimination system permit issued under 40 cfr 122 for land disturbing construction activity 2 transportation facilities except transportation facility construction projects that are part of a larger common plan of development such as local roads within a residential or industrial development 3 land disturbing activities directly involved in the planting growing and harvesting of any plant grown for human or livestock consumption and pasturing or yarding of livestock including sod farms and tree nurseries 4 installation of underground pipe or other utility that is plowed or bored into the ground outside of areas of channelized runoff 5 routine maintenance for project sites that have less than five acres of land disturbance if performed to maintain the original line and grade hydraulic capacity or original purpose of the facility c exceptions this article does not apply to statefunded or conducted sites involving street highway road or bridge construction activities meeting requirements contained in the department of transportation department of natural resources cooperative agreement memorandum of understanding on erosion control note erosion and sediment control for all new construction of one and twofamily dwellings shall be consistent with the standards outlined in wis stats   the city building inspector shall be responsible for review of proposed erosion and sediment control measures and the necessary inspection of the individual home sites d erosion and sediment control plan requirements and performance standards an erosion control plan shall describe how the permit holder and other responsible parties will minimize to the maximum extent practicable soil erosion and the transport of sediment from land disturbing activities to waters of the state or other property the following requirements shall be met on all sites that are applicable to this division 1 all erosion control plans and associated bmps shall comply with the planning design implementation and maintenance requirements of this division 2 all erosion control plans shall by design achieve to the maximum extent practicable a runoff discharge of no more than five tons of sediment per acre per year of the sediment load carried in runoff from initial grading to final stabilization 3 erosion and sediment control bmps may be used alone or in combination to meet the above noted performance standard soil loss prediction tools shall be used to estimate the sediment loss using the appropriate rainfall or runoff factor e general principles for preventing erosion and transport of sediment plans shall incorporate all of the following to the maximum extent practicable 1 maintain existing vegetation especially adjacent to surface waters whenever possible 2 minimize soil compaction and preservation of topsoil 3 minimize the time and overall area of disturbed soil surface exposed to erosive forces phasing and construction sequencing 4 locate bmps so that treatment occurs before runoff enters waters of the state f specific erosion control plan requirements the following applicable minimum requirements shall be addressed in erosion control plans the city may require more stringent erosion and sediment control requirements set forth in this section if the city determines that additional protection is necessary due to protect environmentally sensitive areas or other property 1 access drives and tracking provide access drives for construction vehicles that minimize tracking of soil off site using bmps such as stone tracking pads tire washing or grates minimize runoff from adjacent areas from flowing onto or across the access drive 2 diversion of upslope offsite runoff divert offsite runoff from upslope land if practicable using bmps such as earthen diversion berms and swales prevent erosion of the flow path and the outlet offsite flows that are not diverted need to be accounted for and managed onsite 3 inlet protection protect inlets to storm drains culverts and other storm water conveyance systems from sediment until the site is stabilized 4 soil stockpiles locate soil stockpiles away from channelized flow and no closer than 25 feet from roads ditches lakes streams ponds wetlands or environmental corridors unless otherwise approved by the city soil stockpiles that remain inplace for more than seven days need to be protected if a soil stockpile is inactive for more than 14 days needs to be stabilized 5 cut and fill slopes minimize the length and steepness of proposed cut and fill slopes proper stabilization is required as soon as practicable all slopes built to  slope or steeper require appropriate slope stabilization erosion mat 6 channel flow during construction the discharge of sediment from drainage ways shall be prevented or minimized using appropriate best management practices ditch checks shall be placed within drainage ways and appropriately sized sediment traps or basins installed to capture sediment prior to leaving the site all bmps shall be designed and installed per wdnr technical standards stabilize drainage ways as soon as practicable and utilize appropriate channel erosion mat for all permanent drainage ways temporary swales may require channel erosion mat for stabilization based on duration of use and areas served as directed by the city 7 outlet protection protect outlets from erosion during site dewatering and storm water conveyance velocity dissipation measures may be required at discharge locations or along outfall channels to provide nonerosive flow from the structure in order to maintain and protect downstream watercourses physical and biological characteristics and functions 8 overland flow prevent or minimize sediment from leaving site overland using appropriate bmps such as silt fence and vegetative buffers 9 site dewatering treat pumped water to prevent or minimize sediment discharge the discharge from the dewatering activities shall not cause erosion downstream appropriate bmps shall be used to reduce sediment from the pumped water 10 dust control minimize dust to the maximum extent practicable construction phasing and timely stabilization use of bmps such as site watering or mulch may be necessary if phasing and stabilization do not effectively control dust 11 building and waste material properly dispose of all building and waste material in a timely manner prevent runoff from mingling with waste material 12 sediment clean up clean up all sediment deposits that leave the site by the end of each work day including tracked soil that originates from the permitted site flushing shall not be allowed unless runoff from the flushing is treated prior to discharge from the site 13 final site stabilization establish vegetation with at least a density of 70 percent coverage for all areas that are not paved not covered by a permanent structure or that employ an equivalent permanent stabilization measure stabilization shall be established as final grades are established minimize the areas of exposed soil to the maximum extent practicable this typically requires restoration to be done in stages especially for sites with larger areas of disturbance 14 temporary site stabilization temporary stabilization measures shall be commenced for any disturbed construction site that temporarily ceases land disturbing construction activities for a period exceeding 14 calendar days frozen soil conditions do not exclude the site from this requirement 15 removal of practices temporary bmps that are no longer necessary for erosion and sediment control shall be removed by the permit holder g maintenance of construction site erosion control measures all best management practices necessary to meet the requirements of this article shall be maintained consistent with the maintenance standards contained in the department of natural resources stormwater construction and postconstruction technical standards the permit holder shall be responsible for maintaining the best management practices during the period of land disturbance and land development activity on the site until the site is stabilized and the permit is closed implementation of maintenance standards for best management practices that are not included in the stormwater construction and postconstruction technical standards shall not be permitted unless prior approval is granted by the city 07 erosion control plan requirements no landowner or land user may commence a land disturbance or land development activity subject to this section as described above without receiving prior approval of an erosion control plan for the site and a permit from the city at least one landowner or land user controlling or using the site and desiring to undertake a land disturbing or land developing activity subject to this section shall submit an application for a permit and an erosion control plan or erosion control plan statement and pay an application fee to the city clerk the applicant may file supplemental information with the city clerk to comply with directives resulting from the citys reviews by submitting an application the applicant is authorizing the city to enter the site to obtain information required for the review of the erosion control plan permit fees are referenced in section 16324 1 content of the erosion control plan for land disturbing and land development activities covering one or more acres a points of contact name address email address and telephone number for the following or their designees landowner  developer  project engineer for practice design and certification  persons responsible for installation of erosion control practices  and person responsible for maintenance and inspection of erosion control practices b site map of existing conditions a map of existing site conditions on a scale of at least one inch equals 100 feet showing the site and immediately adjacent areas 1 site boundaries and adjacent lands with landowner names which accurately identify site location 2 lakes streams wetlands channels ditches and other watercourses on and immediately adjacent to the site 3 100year floodplains flood fringes and floodways 4 location of the predominant soil types 5 vegetative cover types and locations 6 locations and dimensions of stormwater drainage systems 7 locations and dimensions of utilities structures roads highways and paving 8 site topography at a contour interval not to exceed two feet 9 any other information deemed necessary by the city c site plan of final conditions a plan of proposed final site conditions on the same scale as the existing site map showing the site changes d site development plan a site development plan including 1 locations and dimensions of all proposed land disturbing and land development activities 2 locations and dimensions of all temporary soil or dirt stockpiles 3 locations and dimensions of all best management practices necessary to meet the requirements of this article 4 schedule of anticipated starting and completion date of each land disturbing or land development activity including the installation of construction site control measures needed to meet the requirements of this article 5 provisions for maintenance of the best management practices during construction 2 content of erosion control plan for land disturbing and land development activities covering less than one acre the erosion control plan will include a narrative that briefly describes the site  description of temporary best management practices intended for use during construction  a construction plan that describes sequence of construction a site stabilization plan and a work schedule the statement will also provide the name address email address and telephone number of the landowner developer project engineer if applicable and the persons responsible for installation maintenance and inspection of erosion control practices the applicant will also submit a simple map that indicates the location of existing and proposed dwellings other buildings and improvements with respect to the property lines it will also show the direction of slopes before and after the land development or land disturbance on the site 3 review of erosion control plan within three working days of receipt of the application a copy thereof together with a copy of the erosion control plan shall be delivered by the clerk to the director of public works or designee for initial review if the director of public works or designee finds the application or erosion control plan to be lacking necessary information or not in compliance with this section the applicant shall be notified of the inadequacy as soon as practical after review the director of public works or designees report on this initial review shall be filed with the plan commission along with the application within 30 days of receipt of the application erosion control plan and fee the director of public works or designee shall review the application and erosion control plan to determine if the requirements of this section are met the director of public works or designee shall approve the plan inform the applicant and issue a permit if the conditions are not met the director of public works or designee shall inform the applicant in writing and may either require needed information or disapprove the plan within 30 days of receipt of needed information the director of public works or designee shall again determine if the plan meets the requirements of this section if the plan is disapproved the director of public works or designee shall inform the applicant in writing of the reasons for the disapproval 4 permits a duration permits shall be valid for a period based on the construction schedule outlined in the approved plans an expiration date will be issued based on the provided information but the initial permit duration shall be no longer than two years extension requests should be made two weeks prior to the expiration date the director of public works or designee may require additional control measures as a condition of the extension if they are necessary to meet the requirements of this article b financial guarantee as a condition of approval and issuance of the permit the city may require the applicant to provide an appropriate irrevocable letter of credit or cash to guarantee a good faith execution of the approved erosion control plan and any permit conditions c permit conditions all permits shall require the permittee to 1 notify the director of public works or designee at least two days before commencing any land disturbing or land development activity associated with the approved plan 2 notify the director of public works or designee of any significant modifications proposed to be made to the approved plan the city may require proposed changes to be submitted for review prior to incorporation into the approved plan or implementation any modifications made during the plan implementation without prior approval by the director of public works or designee is prohibited and may be subject to enforcement action 3 install all best management practices as identified in the approved erosion control plan 4 maintain all road drainage systems stormwater drainage systems best management practices and other facilities identified in the erosion control plan until maintenance responsibility is transferred to another party pursuant to the recorded maintenance agreement 5 repair any damage to adjoining properties municipal facilities or drainage ways resulting from land developing or disturbing activities the city may order immediate repairs or cleanup within road rightsofway or other public lands if the city determines that such damage is caused by activities regulated by a permit under this article with prior approval of the affected landowner the city may also order repairs or cleanup on other affected property 6 inspect the construction control measures within 24 hours after each rain event of 05 inches or more and at least once each week and make needed repairs within 24 hours or as directed by the director of public works or designee an inspection log shall be kept and made available upon request that includes the name of the inspector the date and time of inspection description of present phase of construction inspection findings that includes an assessment of the condition of erosion and sediment control measures and the installation of storm water management bmps and any action or repairs needed or already taken to comply with this article 7 allow the director of public works or designee building inspector or administrator to enter the site for the purpose of inspecting compliance with the erosion control plan and other permit requirements 8 keep a copy of the approved erosion control plan on the site that includes all approved changes 9 the permit holder authorizes the city in accordance with the enforcement procedures under section 16327 to perform any work or operations necessary to bring the erosion control practices into conformance with the approved plan and consents to charging such costs against the financial assurance per subsection 4b of this article or to a special assessment or charge against the property as authorized under wis stats ch 66 subch vii d transfer the city may transfer a permit issued under this article to a new applicant upon written request from the applicant and payment of the corresponding fee the permit transfer shall not take effect until the city verifies in writing that the new applicant has satisfied all conditions of this article including an updated list of responsible parties and the submittal of a new financial guarantee letter of credit or cash per subsection 4b of this section if applicable e summary approval on parcels where land disturbing activities cover less than one acre the director of public works or designee building inspector or administrator may review the erosion control plan and if satisfied that there is minimal opportunity for runoff andor erosion grant a permit hereunder the director of public works or designee building inspector or administrator shall consider the topography of the site and adjacent areas proximity of the site to environmentally sensitive areas the extent of land disturbing activities proposed expected time to complete the proposed land disturbing activities control measures proposed by the landowner or user expected runoff from the subject site and adjacent areas compliance with the department of natural resources construction and postconstruction technical standards and any other factor deemed relevant by the director of public works or designee building inspector or administrator in determining whether to review approve and grant a permit 08 secs 1630016316  reserved division 3  stormwater management applicability this division applies to land development and land disturbing activities which meet the applicability criteria specified in this section specifically it applies to all subdivision condominium commercial and industrial sites the division also applies to land development activities that are smaller than the minimum applicability criteria if such activities are part of a larger common plan of development or sale that meets any of the following applicability criteria even though multiple separate and distinct land development activities may take place at different times on different schedules 1 construction site that consists of one acre or more of land disturbing construction activity 2 construction of a new public or private road of any length 3 construction that ultimately results in the addition of 05 acres or greater of impervious surfaces including smaller individual sites that are part of a common plan or development 4 land development activities regardless of size of the development which the city determines is likely to cause an adverse impact to an environmentally sensitive area or downstream property if no controls are employed 09 design criteria unless prior authorization is given by the director of public works or designee the following methods shall be used in meeting the requirements of this division 1 water quantity components the following methods shall be used in designing components of stormwater structures needed to meet the water quantity standards of this article a peak flow reducing components of stormwater structures shall be designed in accordance with standard engineering practice b runoff volumes and peak flow rates used in designing the water quantity components of stormwater structures shall be based on the nrcs runoff modeling methodology and are based on volume 8 of atlas 14 published by the us department of commerce national oceanic and atmospheric administration national weather service 2013 all peak flow calculations shall use mse 3 rainfall distribution 24hour precipitation data 1year 240 inches 2year 270 inches 10year 381 inches 100year 618 inches c when designing bmps runoff draining to the bmp from offsite shall be taken into account in determining the treatment efficiency of the practice any impact on the efficiency shall be compensated for by increasing the size of the bmp accordingly 2 water quality components the following methods shall be used in designing components of stormwater structures needed to meet the water quality standards of this article a practices shall be designed in accordance with the department of natural resources stormwater construction and postconstruction technical standards b runoff volumes and peak flow rates used in the development of erosion control and storm water management plans in accordance with this article shall be based on united states department of agriculture  natural resources conservation service nrcs methodology models such as slamm p8 or other cityapproved models may be used to evaluate the efficiency of the design in reducing total suspended solids to meet this article models such as slamm recarga or other cityapproved models may be used to evaluate the efficiency of the design in meeting the infiltration requirements of this article models distributed and supported by the wisconsin department of natural resources may be used to determine compliance with calculating the soil loss on construction sites to meet the requirements of this article 10 stormwater management standards a stormwater discharge quantity unless otherwise provided for in this article all land development activities subject to this article shall establish onsite management measures to control the peak flow rates of stormwater discharged from the site infiltration of stormwater runoff shall be incorporated to the maximum extent technically and financially practical to provide volume control in addition to control of peak flows onsite management measures shall be used to meet the following minimum performance standards 1 all stormwater detention facilities shall be designed to restrict postdevelopment flow rates to meet the following multiple storm conditions a oneyear postdeveloped conditions flow rate to discharge at no more than a oneyear predeveloped flow occurring under predevelopment conditions specified in subsection a3 of this section b a tenyear postdeveloped conditions flow rate to discharge at no more than a twoyear predeveloped flow occurring under predevelopment conditions specified in subsection a3 of this section c a 100year postdeveloped conditions flow rate to discharge at no more than a tenyear predeveloped flow rate occurring under predevelopment conditions specified in subsection a3 of this section 2 detention basin designs a dry detention basins all dry detention basins shall be designed with maximum  sideslopes all basins require emergency overflow spillways that can safely pass without overtopping the top of basin the 100year developed conditions storm the top of embankment shall be set at an elevation that provides a minimum of one foot of freeboard above the peak stage elevation of the 100year postdeveloped conditions storm b wet detention basins all wet detention basins shall be designed with maximum  side slope leading to the waters edge the wet basin shall then include a safety shelf at a maximum  slope with a maximum depth of 15 feet below permanent water surface and minimum of eight feet in width the wet basin may then drop at a maximum  side slope below the safety shelf the normal water depth should be no more than eight feet unless otherwise approved by the plan commission all wet detention basins must include an emergency spillway as outlined above all wet detention basins shall be designed with a minimum surface area of a permanent pool based on the particle size and the peak outflow during the oneyear 24hour storm please reference technical standard 1001 for sizing criteria 3 stormwater detention basins may be required to serve as temporary sedimentation facilities during the construction phase of the development the sediment basin shall be designed per the department of natural resources construction and postconstruction technical standards to include a minimum of three feet of sediment storage below the dewatering holes and riser pipes with trash guards all temporary riser pipes and initial stone layer shall be wrapped with filter fabric and protected with six inches of clean stone riprap at the end of construction when the area has been fully restored the temporary riser pipes shall be removed and permanent outlet structures established excess sediment needs to be removed to reestablish sediment storage prior to transferring maintenance responsibility to the maintenance agreement b predevelopment conditions for land developing activities shall assume a good level of land management when the natural resource conservation service tr55 method is used to calculate peak flow discharge rates and runoff values for the predevelopment condition nrcs curve numbers shall not exceed the following for the given soil hydrologic groups when other methods for computing runoff are used they shall assume a comparable predevelopment condition all nondeveloped noncroplands should be represented as meadowgrassland or woodland as appropriate soil hydrologic group a b c d nrcs curve number for meadowgrassland 39 61 71 78 nrcs curve number for woodland 30 55 70 77 nrcs curve number for cropland 55 69 78 83 c protective areas 1 definition the term protective area means an area of land that commences at the top of the channel of lakes streams and rivers or at the delineated boundary of wetlands and that is the greatest of the following widths as measured horizontally from the top of the channel or delineated wetland boundary to the closest impervious surface however in this section the term protective area does not include any area of land adjacent to any stream enclosed within a pipe or culvert such that runoff cannot enter the enclosure at this location a for outstanding resource waters and exceptional resource waters 75 feet b for perennial and intermittent streams identified on the waukesha county gis system 50 feet if there is a discrepancy between the waukesha county gis system and the applicable united states geological survey 75minute series topographic map the more stringent stream identification shall apply c for lakes 50 feet d for wetlands not subject to subsection 1e or f of this section 50 feet e for highly susceptible wetlands 75 feet highly susceptible wetlands include the following types calcareous fens sedge meadows open and coniferous bogs low prairies coniferous swamps lowland hardwood swamps and ephemeral ponds f for less susceptible wetlands ten percent of the average wetland width but no less than ten feet nor more than 30 feet less susceptible wetlands include degraded wetlands dominated by invasive species such as reed canary grass cultivated hydric soils and any gravel pits or dredged material or fill material disposal sites that take on the attributes of a wetland g in subsection 1d to f of this section determinations of the extent of the protective area adjacent to wetlands shall be made on the basis of the sensitivity and runoff susceptibility of the wetland in accordance with the standards and criteria in wis admin nr 10303 h wetland boundary delineation shall be made in accordance with wis admin nr 103081m this subsection does not apply to wetlands that have been completely filled in compliance with all applicable state and federal regulations the protective area for wetlands that have been partially filled in compliance with all applicable state and federal regulations shall be measured from the wetland boundary delineation after fill has been placed where there is a legally authorized wetland fill the protective area standard need not be met in that location i for concentrated flow channels with drainage areas greater than 130 acres ten feet d infiltration performance standard bmps shall be designed installed and maintained to infiltrate runoff in accordance with table 1 below _____ table 1 post development infiltration performance standards % connected impervious surface descriptionexample land uses postdevelopment infiltration volume max effective infiltration area required up to 40% low imperviousness areas such as low density residential parks cemeteries 90% of predevelopment 1% of site more than 40% up to 80% medium imperviousness areas such as medium and high density residential multifamily residential industrial institutional office park 75% of predevelopment 2% of site greater than 80% high imperviousness areas such as commercial strip malls shopping centers commercial downtowns 60% of predevelopment 2% of site notes 1 all percentages are based on average annual rainfall 2 for low density residential developments the postdevelopment infiltration volume shall not be less than 25 percent of the twoyear 24hour storm _____ 1 pretreatment shall be required before infiltrating parking lot and road runoff from commercial industrial and institutional areas the pretreatment shall be designed to protect the infiltration system from clogging prior to scheduled maintenance and to protect groundwater quality in accordance with subsection g of this section pretreatment options may include but are not limited to oilgrease separators sedimentation or biofiltration filtration swales or filter strips all designs shall comply with the department of natural resources construction and postconstruction technical standards 2 infiltration source areas a prohibitions runoff from the following areas may not be infiltrated and may not qualify as contributing to meeting the requirements of this section unless demonstrated to meet the conditions of subsection g of this section 1 areas associated with a tier 1 industrial facility identified in wis admin nr 2162a including storage loading and parking rooftops may be infiltrated with the concurrence of the regulatory authority 2 storage and loading areas of a tier 2 industrial facility identified in wis admin nr 216212b note that runoff from employee and guest parking and rooftop areas of a tier 2 facility may be infiltrated but runoff from the parking area may require pretreatment 3 fueling and maintenance areas rooftops and canopies of fueling and vehicle maintenance areas may be infiltrated 3 exemptions runoff from the following areas may be credited toward meeting the requirement when infiltrated but the decision to infiltrate runoff from these areas is optional a parking areas and access roads less than 5000 square feet for commercial development b parking areas and access roads less than 5000 square feet for industrial development not subject to the prohibitions under subsection c redevelopment unless infiltration requirements were inplace prior for the site being redeveloped d infill development areas less than five acres e roads in commercial industrial and institutional land uses and arterial residential roads 4 location of infiltration practices a prohibitions infiltration practices may not be located in the following areas 1 areas within 1000 feet upgradient or within 100 feet downgradient of direct conduits to groundwater 2 areas within 400 feet of a community water system well as specified in wis admin nr 811164 or within 100 feet of private well as specified in wis admin nr 812084 for runoff infiltrated from commercial including multifamily residential industrial and institutional land uses or regional devices for one and twofamily residential development 3 areas where contaminates of concern as defined in wis admin nr 720032 are present in the soil infiltration will occur e separation distances 1 infiltration practices shall be located so that the characteristics of the soil and the separation distance between the bottom of the infiltration system and the elevation of seasonal high groundwater or the top of bedrock are in the accordance with the following table separation distances and soil characteristics source area separation distance soil characteristic industrial commercial institutional parking lots and roads 5 feet or more filtering layer residential arterial roads 5 feet or more filtering layer roofs draining to subsurface infiltration practices 1 foot or more native or engineered soil with particles finer than course sand roofs draining to surface infiltration practices not applicable all other impervious source areas 3 feet or more filtering layer 2 all storm water bmps shall comply with the applicable provisions under wis admin nr 815 relating to injection wells f infiltration rate exemptions infiltration practices located in the following areas may be credited toward meeting the requirement under the following conditions but the decision to infiltrate under these conditions is optional 1 where the infiltration rate of the soil measured at the proposed bottom of the infiltration system is less than 06 inches per hour using a scientifically credible field test method 2 where the least permeable soil horizon to five feet below the proposed infiltration system using the us department of agriculture method of soils analysis is one of the following sandy clay loam clay loam silty clay loam sandy clay silty clay or clay g alternate runoff uses where storage and reuse of runoff are employed such as to support green roofs landscape watering toilet flushing laundry or irrigation such alternate uses shall be given equal credit toward the infiltration volume required by this section h groundwater protection 1 infiltration systems designed in accordance with this subsection shall to the extent technically and economically feasible minimize the level of pollutants infiltrating to groundwater and shall maintain compliance with the preventive action limit at a point of standards application in accordance with wis admin nr 140 however if sitespecific information indicates that compliance with a preventive action limit is not achievable the infiltration bmp may not be installed or shall be modified to prevent infiltration to the maximum extent practicable 2 the discharge of bmps shall remain below the enforcement standard at the point of standards application i stormwater discharge quality unless otherwise provided for in this article all land development activities subject to this article shall establish onsite management measures to control the quality of stormwater discharged from the site onsite management measures shall be used to meet the following minimum standard 1 for new land development and infill development stormwater discharges shall be treated to remove based on an average annual rainfall basis a minimum of 80 percent of the total suspended solids load as compared to no runoff management controls 2 for redevelopment 40 percent reduction of total suspended solids load from parking areas and roads j stormwater drainage standards all storm drainage facilities shall be installed as indicated on the stormwater management plans required in section 16321 as necessary to serve and resulting from the permitted land development 1 a drainage system shall be designed and constructed by the developer to provide for the proper drainage of the surface water of the land division or redevelopment and the drainage area of which it is a part and contributing offsite areas unless routed around the site 2 the development shall be laid out so as to provide positive drainage away from all buildings and this drainage shall be coordinated with the general storm drainage pattern for the area 3 stormwater drainage systems shall be designed to use the natural drainage and storage capabilities of the site to the fullest extent practicable stormwater drainage systems shall be designed to provide an economical gravity flow drainage system 4 bridges and culverts all new and replacement culverts and bridges over waterways shall be designed so as to accommodate according to the categories listed below the designated flood event without overtopping the adjacent related roadway railway track sidewalk or footpath 5 minor and collector streets used or intended to be used primarily for access to abutting properties a tenyear recurrence interval flood discharge 6 arterial streets and highways other than freeways and expressways used or intended to be used primarily to carry heavy volumes of traffic a 50year recurrence interval flood discharge the depth of flow over the top of minor collector arterial streets and highways shall not exceed six inches above the centerline during the 100year recurrence interval flood discharge bridges and culverts over waterways shall be designed to facilitate fish passage of hydraulic drops maintenance of low flow channels and minimization of excess stream enclosures 7 street drainage all streets shall be provided with an adequate storm drainage system the street storm drainage system shall serve as the minor drainage system and shall be designed to carry street adjacent land and building stormwater drainage stormwater shall not be directed into the sanitary sewer system within the proposed subdivision development in order to provide an acceptable level of access to property and traffic service the drainage system shall be designed to provide two clear lanes of moving traffic on arterial streets and one tenfoot lane for moving traffic on collector and land access streets during the tenyear critical duration storm temporary accumulations of storm runoff from ponding or flowing water in or near minor system components shall be permitted during events greater than the tenyear storm provided such accumulations do not encroach on any traffic lane of any collector or arterial street nor be more than six inches deep as measured at the center line of any local street 8 offstreet drainage the design of the offstreet drainage system shall include the entire watershed affecting the land division and shall be extended to a watercourse storm sewer or ditch adequate to receive the storm drainage when the drainage system is outside of the street rightofway the developer shall provide an easement for the maintenance of said system as described in subsection j13 of this section 9 downstream drainage responsibility in situations where the city determines that a developments stormwater contributions cause the existing downstream facilities to be exceeded for the design storm the city reserves the right where legally possible to enter into a costsharing agreement with the owner or permittee for improvements to said downstream facilities 10 drainage piping systems unless otherwise approved by the director of public works or designee all drainage piping of 12inch diameter and greater size in street rightsofway shall be constructed of reinforced concrete pipe as follows pipe size required class 12 class v 15 class iv 18 or larger class iii 11 storm sewer manholes shall be 48inch minimum diameter catch basins with twofoot sumps shall be provided at all storm inlets 12 agricultural drains agricultural drain tiles that are disturbed during construction shall be restored reconnected or connected to public storm drainage facilities 13 open channel systems where open channels are used in either the minor or major drainage system they shall be designed so as to minimize maintenance requirements they shall be also be designed to carry the peak flows from a tenyear 24hour design storm side slopes shall not be steeper than a threetoone slope unless approved by the director of public works or designee 14 protection of drainage systems the developer shall adequately protect all ditches to the satisfaction of the director of public works or designee open channels shall be restored with appropriate materials matting riprap etc as determined by director of public works or designee based on calculated flows and velocities 15 drainage easements where a land division development or redevelopment is traversed by a watercourse drainageway storm sewer channel or stream a the developer or landowner shall provide a stormwater easement or drainage rightofway conforming substantially to the lines of such watercourse or storm sewer and such further width for construction or both as will be adequate for the purpose and as may be necessary to comply with this section  or b the watercourse drainageway storm sewer channel or stream may be relocated in such a manner that the maintenance of adequate drainage will be assured when channels are relocated the developer or owner shall provide a stormwater easement or drainage rightofway conforming to the lines of the relocated watercourse and such further width for construction or both c whenever possible drainage shall be maintained in an easement by an open channel with vegetated banks and adequate width for maximum potential volume flow in all cases such easements shall be wide enough to convey the tenyear critical duration storm for the minor drainage system the drainage easement shall not be less than 20 feet in width and should be 30 feet in width when site conditions allow 16 structure protection and safety flows generated by the 100year critical duration storm under planned land use conditions may exceed the design capacity of conveyance systems but shall not come in contact with any buildings for buildings designed for human occupation on a regular basis the following additional requirements shall apply a the lowest elevation of the structure that is exposed to the ground surface shall be a minimum of two feet above the maximum water elevation produced by the 100year critical duration storm including flows storm water bmp that is designed to store water at a depth of three feet or greater b all structures shall be setback a distance as follows from the closest edge of the water elevation produced by the 100year critical duration storm 1 residential structures 25 feet 2 commercial and industrial structures ten feet k exceptions the requirements for onsite stormwater management measures established in subsections a c of this section are not applicable in areas which are determined by the plan commission to be covered by an approved stormwater management system plan which was developed and approved as an alternative stormwater management planning approach to carrying out onsite measures consistent with the purpose and intent of this article in such cases the recommendations of the approved stormwater management system plan shall be applied either installation of stormwater management provisions recommended to be included on the development site being considered andor payment of a fee as set forth in section 16324 these minimum requirements may also be waived in whole or in part by the plan commission in cooperation with the director of public works or designee upon written request of the applicant provided that at least one of the following conditions applies 1 provisions are made to manage stormwater by an offsite facility this requires meeting all the following conditions the offsite facility is in place  is designed and adequately sized to provide a level of stormwater control equal to or greater than that which would be afforded by onsite practices meeting the requirements of this division  and the facility has a legally obligated entity responsible for its longterm operation and maintenance 2 director of public works or designee finds that meeting the minimum onsite management requirements is infeasible due to space or site restrictions l fee in lieu of onsite stormwater management practices where the plan commission in cooperation with the director of public works or designee waives all or part of the minimum onsite stormwater management requirements or where the waiver is based on the provision of adequate stormwater facilities provided by a responsible entity downstream the applicant may be required to pay a fee set by the common council in setting the fee for land development projects the city shall consider an equitable distribution of the cost of land engineering design construction and maintenance as set forth in wis stats  6655 m general considerations for onsite and offsite stormwater management measures the following considerations shall be observed in managing stormwater runoff 1 natural topography and land cover features such as natural swales natural depressions native soil infiltrating capacity and natural groundwater recharge areas shall be preserved and used for stormwater infiltration and conveyance to the extent practical and reasonably feasible to meet the requirements of this section 2 emergency overland flow for all stormwater facilities shall be provided to prevent exceeding the safe capacity of downstream property or public safety n exemptions 1 internally drained sites the site is internally drained and will not discharge runoff from the site after development occurs the site must be evaluated using post developed conditions assuming frozen conditions cn   98 no infiltration and the 100year critical duration storm when determining safe structure elevations 2 site conditions it may be impracticable to meet the requirements due to site conditions such as slopes soils proximity to structures or desirable trees limited site dimensions surrounding land uses the potential for groundwater contamination public health or safety problems or other factors beyond the control of the developer no site shall be entitled to an exemption under this section due solely to the size of the proposed land development activity in relation to the parcel size however the city shall provide special consideration in granting exemptions under this section for the following type of sites a redevelopment sites  b infill development areas less than five acres  c highway projects where limited public rightofway land is available for the installation of storm water bmps 11 permit requirements and procedures a permit required no landowner or land operator may undertake a land development activity subject to this article without receiving a permit from the city prior to commencing the proposed activity the permit will be a combined permit for erosion control and stormwater management b permit application and fee unless otherwise excepted by this article any landowner or operator desiring a permit shall submit to the city a permit application made on a form provided by the city for that purpose at least one landowner or land user controlling or using the site and desiring to undertake a land developing activity subject to this section shall submit an application for a permit a stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement erosion control plan and pay required fees to the city clerk the applicant may file supplemental information with the city clerk to comply with directives resulting from the citys initial review by submitting an application the applicant is authorizing the city to enter the site to obtain information required for the review of the erosion control plan stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement 1 unless otherwise excepted by this article a permit application must be accompanied by the following in order that the permit application be considered by the director of public works or designee a stormwater management plan with a maintenance agreement erosion control plan any payment of fees in lieu prior to permit issuance a nonrefundable permit administration fee and signed professional services reimbursement form 2 the erosion control plan shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 16299  the stormwater management plan shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 16321  the maintenance agreement shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 16322  and fees shall be those established by the plan commission as set forth in section 16324 c review and approval of permit application the stormwater management plan and maintenance agreement will be reviewed along the same timeline as that for review of the erosion control plan as specified in section 162993 d permit conditions all permits issued under this article shall be subject to the following conditions and holders of permits issued under this article shall be deemed to have accepted these conditions the director of public works or designee may suspend or revoke a permit for violation of a permit condition following written notification of the permittee an action by the city to suspend or revoke this permit may be appealed in accordance with section 16327 1 compliance with this permit does not relieve the permit holder of the responsibility to comply with other applicable federal state and local laws and regulations the city may require applicant to obtain other permits or plan approvals prior to issuing a permit 2 the permit holder shall design install and maintain all structural and nonstructural stormwater management measures in accordance with the approved erosion control plan stormwater management plan maintenance agreement and the permit a copy of all approved plans shall be maintained at the construction site all times during normal business hours until all temporary bmps have been removed 3 the permit holder shall notify the director of public works or designee within 48 hours of commencing any work in conjunction with the stormwater management plan and within three working days upon completion of the stormwater management practices if required as a special condition the permit holder shall make additional notification according to a schedule set forth by the plan commission in cooperation with the director of public works or designee so that practice installations can be inspected during construction 4 completed structural stormwater management practices must pass a final inspection to determine if they are built in accordance with the approved stormwater management plan and ordinance the director of public works or designee shall notify the permit holder in writing of any changes required in such practices to bring them into compliance with conditions of this permit the practice installation required as part of this division shall be certified as built by a licensed professional engineer representing the permit holder 5 the permit holder shall notify the director of public works or designee of any significant modifications it intends to make to an approved stormwater management or erosion control plan the director of public works or designee may require that the proposed modifications be submitted for approval prior to incorporation into the stormwater management or erosion control plan and execution 6 the permit holder shall maintain all stormwater management practices specified in the approved stormwater management plan until the practices either become the responsibility of the city or are transferred to subsequent private owners as specified in the approved maintenance agreement 7 the permit holder shall allow access to the director of public works or designee building inspector or administrator for the purpose of inspecting the property for compliance with the approved stormwater management and erosion control plan and permit 8 if so directed by the city the permit holder shall repair at the permit holders own expense all damage to adjoining properties municipal facilities and drainage ways caused by erosion siltation stormwater runoff or equipment tracking from the holders permit site where such damage is caused by activities that are not in compliance with the approved stormwater management or erosion control plan 9 the permit holder authorizes the city following written notification to perform any work or operations necessary to bring stormwater management or erosion control measures into conformance with the approved stormwater management or erosion control plan and consents to placing associated costs upon the tax roll as a special lien against the property or to charging such costs against the financial guarantee posted for the project 10 where a stormwater management plan involves changes in direction increases in peak rate andor total volume of runoff off a site the planning commission in cooperation with the director of public works or designee may require the permittee to make appropriate legal arrangements with adjacent property owners concerning the prevention of endangerment to downstream property or public safety 11 the permit holder is subject to the enforceable actions detailed in section 16327 if the permit holder fails to comply with the terms of this permit 12 letter of credit or cash as a condition of approval and issuance of the permit the plan commission shall require the applicant to provide an appropriate irrevocable letter of credit or cash to guarantee good faith execution of the approved erosion control and stormwater management plan maintenance agreement and permit conditions e permit duration permits shall be valid for a period based on the construction schedule outlined in the approved plans with an initial maximum duration of two years an expiration date will be issued based on the provided information extension requests should be made two weeks prior to the expiration date the director of public works or designee may require additional control measures as a condition of the extension if they are necessary to meet the requirements of this article 12 stormwater management plans a plan requirements the stormwater management plan required under section 16320b shall contain any information the director of public works or designee may need to evaluate the environmental characteristics of the area affected by the land development activity the potential impacts of the proposed development upon the quality and quantity of stormwater discharges the potential impacts upon water resources and drainage utilities and the effectiveness and acceptability of proposed stormwater management measures in meeting the performance standards set forth in this article stormwater management plans shall contain at a minimum the following information 1 name address email address and telephone number for the following or their designees landowner  developer  project engineer for practice design and certification  persons responsible for installation of erosion control and stormwater management measures  persons responsible for maintenance of stormwater measures prior to the transfer if any of maintenance responsibility to another party 2 a proper legal description of the property proposed to be developed referenced to the us public land survey system or to block and lot numbers within a recorded land subdivision plat 3 existing predevelopment site conditions including a a site map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet the site map shall show the following site location  predominant soil types and hydrologic soil groups  existing cover type and condition with accompanying runoff curve numbers  topographic contours of the site not to exceed twofoot contour interval  topography and drainage network including enough of the contiguous properties to show runoff patterns onto from the site  watercourses that may affect or be affected by runoff from the site  flow path and direction for all stormwater conveyance sections including time of travel and time of concentration applicable to each  watershed boundaries used in determinations of peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes from the site  lakes streams wetlands channels ditches and other watercourses on and immediately adjacent to the site  limits of the 100year floodplain  location of municipal or community wells located within 400 feet and private wells located within 100 feet of stormwater detention ponds infiltration basins or infiltration trenches  delineation of wellhead protection areas delineated pursuant to wis admin nr 81116 b computations of the peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes from each discharge point in the development including analysis of the capacity of downstream drainage conveyance systems at a minimum computations must be made for the following 24hour storm events oneyear twoyear  tenyear  and 100year all major assumptions used in developing input shall be clearly stated the areas used in making the calculations shall be clearly crossreferenced to the required maps c a storm sewer system map showing the location size material type and invert elevations of all existing and proposed storm sewers 4 site development plan including a a narrative summary of the overall storm water management plan including an explanation of the bmps proposed and why they were chosen how the plan meets the requirements of this article an explanation of the provisions to preserve and use natural topography and land cover features to minimize changes in peak flow runoff rates and volumes to surface waters and wetlands and explanation of any restrictions on stormwater management measures in the development area imposed by wellhead protection plans and ordinances b a site map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet showing proposed land uses including vegetative cover type and accompanying runoff curve numbers  proposed topographic contours of the site not to exceed two feet  proposed drainage network including enough of the contiguous properties to show runoff patterns onto from the site  locations and dimensions of drainage and access easements  flow path and direction for all stormwater conveyance sections including time of travel and time of concentration applicable to each  location and type of all stormwater management conveyance and treatment practices including the onsite and offsite tributary drainage area  location and type of conveyance system that will carry runoff from the drainage and treatment practices to the nearest adequate outlet such as a curbed street storm drain or natural drainage way  watershed boundaries used in determinations of peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes  and amendments to lakes streams wetlands channels ditches and other watercourses on and immediately adjacent to the site c computations of the peak flow discharge rates and discharge volumes from each discharge point in the development including analysis of the capacity of downstream drainage conveyance systems at a minimum computations must be made for the following 24hour storms oneyear twoyear  tenyear  and 100year all major assumptions used in developing input parameters shall be clearly stated the areas used in making the calculations shall be clearly crossreferenced to the required maps d investigations of soils and groundwater required for the placement and design of stormwater management measures adequate soil boring information must be provided based on wdnr technical standards 1002 e design computations including type size and location for all pipes open channels and other proposed storm water conveyance systems and all applicable assumptions crosssections of proposed conveyances may be required if determined critical f detailed crosssections and profiles of each bmp showing all critical design features side slopes structures soil profiles and applicable elevations including seasonal highwater table g detailed drawings with specifications for inlets andor outlets h detailed construction notes explaining all necessary procedures to be followed to properly implement the plan including seeding and restoration specifications timing and sequencing of construction and any temporary measures needed to protect bmps during the construction phase b exceptions director of public works or designee may prescribe alternative submittal requirements for applicants seeking an exemption to onsite stormwater management performance standards under section 16319c c waivers director of public works or designee may waive some of the requirements of subsection a of this section to accommodate smaller scale projects 13 maintenance agreement a maintenance agreement required the maintenance agreement required for stormwater management measures under section 16320 shall be an agreement between the city and the permittee to provide for maintenance of stormwater management practices beyond the duration period of this permit the agreement or recordable document shall be filed with the city clerk and recorded with the waukesha county register of deeds so that it is binding upon all subsequent owners of land served by the stormwater management measures b agreement provisions the maintenance agreement shall contain the following provisions 1 identification of the stormwater management measures their design components and description of all long term maintenance activities that will likely be required for each for each measure included in the agreement and an estimated time interval between each activity 2 identification of the landowners organization or municipality responsible for maintenance of the stormwater management measures for subdivisions all storm water management measures that collect runoff from more than one lot shall be located on outlots unless otherwise requested by the permittee and approved by the city for all privately owned outlots ownership shall be by proportional undividable interest of all properties that are within the control of the permittee and drain to the bmp however the permittee may combine ownership of more than one storm water management measure within the site 3 the landowners organization or city shall maintain stormwater management practices in accordance with the stormwater practice maintenance provisions contained in the approved stormwater management plan submitted under section 16321 4 the director of public works or designee building inspector or administrator is authorized to access the property to conduct inspections of stormwater practices as necessary to ascertain that the practices are being maintained and operated in accordance with the approved stormwater management plan 5 the city representative conducting the inspection shall maintain public records of the results of the site inspections shall inform the designated entity responsible for maintenance of the inspection results and shall specifically indicate any corrective actions required to bring the stormwater management practice into proper working condition 6 upon notifying the designated entity of maintenance problems which require correction the specified corrective actions shall be taken within 24 hours or as specified by the city 7 the city is authorized to perform the corrected actions identified in the inspection report if the landowner does not make the required corrections in the specified time period the costs and expenses shall be entered on the tax roll as a special assessment against the property and collected with any other taxes levied thereon for the year in which the work is completed 14 financial guarantee a establishment of the guarantee 1 the director of public works or designee may require the applicant to furnish the city with a financial guarantee the form and type of which shall be acceptable to the city prior to release of a permit the financial guarantee shall be in an amount determined by the director of public works or designee to be the estimated cost of constructing and installing the erosion control and stormwater management practices and the estimated cost of maintenance during the period which the designated party in the maintenance agreement has maintenance responsibility a financial guarantee shall not be required of departments boards commissions public offices and corporations having the authority of eminent domain under wis stats ch 32 2 the financial guarantee shall be sufficient to cover all phases of the plan from clearing and stockpiling operations to final grading landscaping and maintenance and shall give the city the authority to use the funds to complete the project if the applicant defaults or does not properly implement the approved plan b conditions for release conditions for release of the financial guarantee are as follows 1 the director of public works or designee shall release the portion of the financial guarantee pertaining to installation of erosion and sediment control and stormwater management practices minus any costs incurred by the city to complete installation once the site has been stabilized with vegetative cover including vegetative cover required as a result of utility distribution system installation and the best management practice installation required as a part of this article has been certified as built by a licensed professional engineer 2 the director of public works or designee shall release the portion of the financial security established to assure maintenance
